answer_llm: The course contains the bare minimum of theoretical content. The focus is primarily on practice, and theory is covered only at an intuitive level. For example, while using logistic regression, the course does not delve into deriving the gradient update rule but instead focuses on how to use logistic regression and interpret the results.
answer_orig:
The bare minimum. The focus is more on practice, and we'll cover the theory only on the intuitive level.: https://mlbookcamp.com/article/python
For example, we won't derive the gradient update rule for logistic regression (there are other great courses for that), but we'll cover how to use logistic regression and make sense of the results.

To prepare for the course, it is important to know some Python basics. Specifically, you should be familiar with:

- How to run a Jupyter notebook.
- How to import libraries and understand what libraries are.
- How to declare a variable and understand what variables are.
- Some important operations regarding data analysis.

It is also recommended to follow the "Learn Python Basics for Data Analysis" course on the OpenClassrooms e-learning platform if you need to brush up on these basics.
answer_orig:
Check this article. If you know everything in this article, you know enough. If you don’t, read the article and join the coursIntroduction to Pythone too :)
Introduction to Python – Machine Learning Bookcamp
You can follow this English course from the OpenClassrooms e-learning platform, which is free and covers the python basics for data analysis: Learn Python Basics for Data Analysis - OpenClassrooms . It is important to know some basics such as: how to run a Jupyter notebook, how to import libraries (and what libraries are), how to declare a variable (and what variables are) and some important operations regarding data analysis.
(Mélanie Fouesnard)

This course will help you understand the basics such as how to declare a variable and other important operations regarding data analysis.
answer_orig:
Check this article. If you know everything in this article, you know enough. If you don’t, read the article and join the coursIntroduction to Pythone too :)
Introduction to Python – Machine Learning Bookcamp
You can follow this English course from the OpenClassrooms e-learning platform, which is free and covers the python basics for data analysis: Learn Python Basics for Data Analysis - OpenClassrooms . It is important to know some basics such as: how to run a Jupyter notebook, how to import libraries (and what libraries are), how to declare a variable (and what variables are) and some important operations regarding data analysis.
(Mélanie Fouesnard)

question: Is there a guide to set up TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu?

answer_llm: To configure GPU support for TensorFlow on your Ubuntu machine, you need to set up CUDA and cuDNN. The process can be a bit overwhelming, but here is a simplified guide available through this article: [ML Zoomcamp 2023 Project](https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/). Additionally, make sure you have the proper Nvidia drivers installed, which can be found [here](https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx). You can find more detailed instructions on the [TensorFlow installation page](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#linux_1) for setting up CUDA in your environment. Once these steps are followed, you should be able to perform training and inference with GPU support in TensorFlow.
answer_orig: Here is an article that worked for me: https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/
question: How do I configure GPU support for TensorFlow on my Ubuntu machine?

question: Can you direct me to a resource for installing TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu?

answer_llm: To set up TensorFlow GPU on Ubuntu, you'll need to install CUDA and cuDNN. The procedure can be quite complex, but a simplified guide can help. You can refer to this article for detailed instructions: [ML Zoomcamp 2023 Project](https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/). Moreover, make sure to install the necessary Nvidia drivers and follow the TensorFlow installation process for Linux from their official documentation: [TensorFlow installation for Linux](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#linux_1). Additionally, you'll need to install [CUDA toolkit](https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive) and [cuDNN](https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download) correctly to allow GPU support.
answer_orig: Here is an article that worked for me: https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/

answer_llm:
To join a channel in Slack, you can follow these steps: 

1. Click on “All channels” at the top of your left sidebar. If you can't see this option, click on “More” to find it.
2. Browse through the list of public channels in your workspace, or use the search bar to find a channel by its name or description.
3. Select a channel from the list to view it.
4. Click on "Join Channel."

For a detailed guide, you can visit the Slack help article: [Join a channel](https://slack.com/help/articles/205239967-Join-a-channel).
answer_orig:
Here’s how you join a in Slack: https://slack.com/help/articles/205239967-Join-a-channel
Click “All channels” at the top of your left sidebar. If you don't see this option, click “More” to find it.
Browse the list of public channels in your workspace, or use the search bar to search by channel name or description.
Select a channel from the list to view it.
Click Join Channel.
